title: Suspicious Email Request
description: You receive an email from what appears to be your company's IT department asking you to verify your account credentials immediately to avoid service disruption. The email contains a link to a login page.
question: What should you do?
options: Do not click the link. Contact your IT department directly to verify the request
Click the link and enter your credentials to avoid service disruption
Forward the email to colleagues to warn them about a potential issue
Reply to the email asking for more information
feedback: Legitimate IT departments will never ask for credentials via email. Always verify suspicious requests through official channels before taking any action. This is a common phishing attempt.

title: Unexpected USB Drive
description: You find an unlabeled USB drive in the parking lot of your office building. It has no identifying information but looks professionally manufactured.
question: What is the safest action to take?
options: Plug it into your work computer to identify the owner
Turn it in to lost and found or security without plugging it in
Take it home and plug it into your personal computer
Format the drive and use it for your own purposes
feedback: Unknown USB devices can contain malware designed to automatically infect computers when plugged in. This is a common social engineering tactic. Always hand found devices to security professionals.
